author: By Dwight Garner
title: Patricia Highsmith Lived Extravagantly, and Took Copious Notes
description: The writer’s newly released diaries and notebooks, spanning five decades from 1941 to 1995, are a record of hard work, wild nightlife and passionate love affairs.
content: Youth is wasted on the young, it’s said. It wasn’t wasted on Patricia Highsmith.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden and Constant Méheut
title: Police Officer Stabbed on French Riviera, Authorities Say
description: Gérald Darmanin, France’s interior minister, said an assailant had stabbed an officer in Cannes. The motive for the attack was not immediately clear.
content: PARIS — A French police officer was attacked and stabbed as he sat in his patrol car early Monday morning in the city of Cannes, on the French Riviera, according to the French authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Joe Pera and the Surprising Pleasures of Gentle Humor
description: Don’t expect twists in these bits. The standup, who will be at the New York Comedy Festival, has devised a calming aesthetic with rewards of its own.
content: To bore an audience is one of the worst things a performer can do. It’s among the trustiest truisms of show business. But what if our anxious culture has become so crowded with fast-talking agitators, hyperventilators and disrupters that something soothing and subdued becomes refreshing? Is it possible that the most exciting move is to embrace dullness?
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Nov. 8, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 8, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Even Without Derrick Henry, Titans Find a Way to Win Again
description: After routing Jacksonville, outlasting Buffalo, demolishing Kansas City and thwarting Indianapolis, Tennessee beat the Rams.
content: The Tennessee Titans played their first of what will be several games without Derrick Henry on Sunday night, and because they won that game against the Los Angeles Rams in an unequivocal romp, it would be irresponsible, really, to move into the next paragraph without again acknowledging that achievement: The Titans, playing without the rhinoceros of a running back so central to their identity, traveled across the country and swamped the Rams — as in, the had-lost-once-since-Labor-Day-Rams — by 28-16 at SoFi Stadium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan DiTrolio
title: How to Photograph Annie Leibovitz
description: Gillian Laub was given a daunting — and thrilling — assignment: Capture the famed photographer Annie Leibovitz on camera. Here’s how she got the shot.
content: An article published in The New York Times’s Arts section last week, “A ‘Conceptual Artist’ at Work,”  explores the life, artistry and new book of the photographer Annie Leibovitz. The portraits of Ms. Leibovitz that accompany the article, shot by the photographer Gillian Laub, are just as illuminating: Intimate and inviting, the photos capture the vulnerable, often unseen side of a person who is normally behind the camera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor and Eduardo Medina
title: Missing Girl Is Rescued After Using Hand Signal From TikTok
description: The girl flashed the hand signal from a car on a Kentucky interstate, the authorities said. It was created as a way for people to indicate that they are at risk of abuse and need help.
content: A girl reported missing from Asheville, N.C., and in distress in the passenger seat of a car traveling through Kentucky appeared to be waving through the window to passing cars on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Armstrong, Concepción de León and Heather Murphy
title: ‘Her touch, her kiss’: A couple reunites as the U.S. reopens to many vaccinated travelers.
description: Romantic partners and families rejoiced as they met in airports after long months of separation because of pandemic travel restrictions.
content: As the United States reopened to fully vaccinated travelers from dozens of countries on Monday, it was a morning of joyous reunions, some hard-earned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: In hard-hit Romania, the virus is surging as vaccine hesitancy spreads.
description: As a new wave of the coronavirus pandemic crashed over Eastern Europe last month, devastating unvaccinated populations, an Orthodox Church bishop in southern Romania offered solace to his flock: “Don’t be fooled by what you see on TV — don’t be scared of Covid.”
content: As a new wave of the coronavirus pandemic crashed over Eastern Europe last month, devastating unvaccinated populations, an Orthodox Church bishop in southern Romania offered solace to his flock: “Don’t be fooled by what you see on TV — don’t be scared of Covid.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marian Bull
title: A Quiet Studio With a Home-Court Advantage
description: Tim Burns, who trains basketball players, including N.B.A. pros, found a studio in Brooklyn for $3,150. His favorite amenity: the basketball court.
content: If you’re unhappy with your New York City apartment, it helps to have a relative who is a real estate agent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: What Is Unique About Your Hometown?
description: What is the place where you live known for? How is that celebrated? Should your hometown be celebrated for something else? If so, how?
content: Where do you live? What sets it apart from other places? Do you know your area’s history? What is especially interesting about your hometown?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Is California’s Fire Season Over?
description: What’s next depends on what part of the state you live in.
content: You probably know that California’s recent torrential storms were not enough to end the drought. The state has been so parched for so long that the rains, while welcome, did not provide much more than a few drops in the metaphorical bucket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: ‘I Think We’re Cousins?’: ‘Ain’t Too Proud’ Performers Realize Link
description: A post in a family Facebook group led an actor and a musician in the Broadway musical to discover that they are distant cousins.
content: Before the curtain comes down each night on “Ain’t Too Proud,” the Broadway jukebox musical that follows the rise of the R&B group the Temptations, the cast turns around in unison and lowers down to one knee as the lights go up to illuminate the show’s 17-piece band.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Why the Media Loves Labor Now
description: At a moment of political turmoil, economic change and a pandemic-driven focus on how we work, labor has become a hot news beat.
content: The top story in the weekly print edition of The Chief-Leader, a publication that has long covered New York City’s civil servants, is often about the hottest job listing in town. Last week, it was, “Bus Operator Jobs With MTA Starting at $23.84 an Hour.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Northern Ireland’s health minister is suing Van Morrison over Covid-19 criticism.
description: The Belfast-born singer-songwriter has embraced conspiracy theories and criticized restrictions to slow the spread of the coronavirus. Last year, he released a single called “No More Lockdown.”
content: Northern Ireland’s health minister has sued Van Morrison, who has said the minister’s handling of Covid-19 restrictions was “very dangerous.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Refreshingly Bitter, This Spritz Is Ready to Move
description: Ramona’s latest canned offering is a light Amarino spritz from Italy.
content: The sommelier Jordan Salcito was an early player on the canned cocktail scene when she introduced her first Ramona, a sparkling grapefruit wine spritz, back in 2016. The company’s portfolio of easy-drinking spritzes has grown since then and this month it has introduced Amarino Spritz, a lighthearted interpretation of the Italian aperitivo. Ms. Salcito said she was inspired to create this flavor after learning about the additives and artificial coloring agents in classic bitter amaro spirits used to make spritzes. All Ramona drinks are certified organic in Italy. The Amarino, not too sweet with a refreshing bitter touch, delivers a mere 5 percent alcohol; a shot of gin makes it more serious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: They’ll Be So Blue Thinking About You
description: Rogue Creamery offers two gift boxes filled with blue cheeses from Oregon.
content: It’s about the time for the influx of gift boxes. Among the thousands of them on offer, there are two that are particularly well focused from Rogue Creamery in Central Point, Ore., a dairy that specializes in the blue cheeses (and Cheddars). The cultures for the blue are based on a recipe from Roquefort, France. The new Blue Christmas box contains a quarter-wheel (about 19 ounces) of the dairy’s prizewinning Rogue River Blue Cheese, a buttery, herbaceous cheese with a touch of tyrosine crunch wrapped in grape leaves, along with accouterments, including a cutting board. Another option would be the dairy’s sampler of five blues: Bluehorn, Caveman, Crater Lake, Oregon and Smokey, without the Rogue River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Surico
title: The Popularity of E-Bikes Isn’t Slowing Down
description: Motorized bicycles are outselling all-electric cars and have the potential to transform urban transit.
content: There is a joke told in transit circles about people who ride electric bicycles: How do you know if someone has an e-bike? They’ll tell you. The idea, of course, is that users of the battery-powered two-wheelers tend to be proselytizers for the technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Man Shot by Kyle Rittenhouse Describes the Encounter on a Kenosha Street
description: The testimony underscores the prosecutors’ challenge in disproving a self-defense claim. Gaige Grosskreutz, who was armed, was shot while responding to an earlier shooting.
content: KENOSHA, Wis. — Gaige Grosskreutz, the only person who survived being shot by Kyle Rittenhouse in Kenosha, Wis., in August 2020, took the witness stand on Monday and described the instant he faced Mr. Rittenhouse, who had just fired several shots with a semiautomatic rifle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Obama, in Climate Speech Focused on Youth, Has Words for Republicans, Too.
description: The former president, who helped seal the Paris climate accord, spoke at COP26 in Glasgow.
content: GLASGOW — Former President Barack Obama, who helped to seal the Paris climate agreement six years ago, returned to an international climate summit here to rally nations to heal the planet, acknowledging the enormous complexity of the crisis but arguing that humanity has the capacity to create a safer, healthier world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: More Than Just Olive Oil
description: Colive is a project designed to bridge the divide between north and south Cyprus.
content: Colive from Cyprus is an innovative olive oil made with olives from either side of the green line dividing the Turkish-occupied north and the independent south. Hasan Siber, an olive oil expert whose family is native to the Greek-speaking southern part of the island, wanted to show the world the quality of Cypriot olive oil and to “bridge the divide in Cyprus,” as he said in an email. He brings the handpicked olives from the harvest in the north across to the south where they are cold-pressed within 24 hours with olives from the south. The greenish-gold oil — mostly from Kypriaki olives, an indigenous variety, with some koroneiki and arbequina — has a grassy aroma and warm richness finishing with a touch of bitterness. It complies with the international regulations for extra virgin and is now available in the United States. The company is donating 10 percent of profits from each bottle to organizations promoting peace and education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Emily Anthes
title: Scientists Fight a New Source of Vaccine Misinformation: Aaron Rodgers
description: The Green Bay Packers quarterback, one of the most visible athletes in the country, last week used anti-vaccination rhetoric as his reasoning for not getting vaccinated against Covid-19.
content: This spring, he was auditioning to be the host of “Jeopardy!” Nearly every day, he pops up on television ads for national brands like State Farm insurance. And on Sundays this fall, he has led the Green Bay Packers to a division-best 7-2 record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Penn and Andrew Stein
title: Bill Clinton Saved His Presidency. Here’s How Biden Can, Too.
description: The new bipartisan infrastructure law is a first step, but only a broader course correction to the center will give Democrats a fighting chance.
content: Swing voters in two blue-leaning states just sent a resounding wake-up call to the Biden administration: If Democrats remain on their current course and keep coddling and catering to progressives, they could lose as many as 50 seats and control of the House in the 2022 midterm elections. There is a way forward now for President Biden and the Democratic Party: Friday’s passage of the bipartisan physical infrastructure bill is a first step, but only a broader course correction to the center will give Democrats a fighting chance in 2022 and a shot at holding on to the presidency in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrea Long Chu
title: The Emily Ratajkowski You’ll Never See
description: With her new book, the model tries to escape the oppressions of the male gaze. So our writer is keeping some of her secrets.
content: I’m not going to tell you what the hostess said to Emily Ratajkowski. Instead, I will tell you this: We are having lunch at a restaurant. We consult the restaurant’s menu, which boasts many items. Ratajkowski, a model who first became famous for appearing naked in a music video, orders something. I, who have never been in a music video but have been naked many times, also order something. We remark casually on the restaurant’s ambience, noting its proximity to various locations. I turn on my recorder. Each of us is wearing clothes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: Documentaries on Kevin Garnett and Jake Burton Carpenter
description: A pair of new documentaries, one on HBO and one on Showtime, look at two very different sports figures.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Nov. 8-14. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: Marking a Different Thanksgiving Tradition, From West Africa
description: Liberian Americans have a complicated relationship with their holiday that plays out in the foods they make and the ways they reflect on a proud and difficult history.
content: On a pivotal day in July, a nation declared its independence. Years later, it set aside a day in November to celebrate Thanksgiving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu, Heather Murphy and Concepción de León
title: With Tears, Hugs and Balloons, U.S. Allows Vaccinated Foreign Travelers to Enter
description: On Monday, after more than 18 months, restrictions that kept families separated and cost the global travel industry hundreds of billions of dollars were lifted.
content: The United States reopened its borders for vaccinated foreign travelers on Monday, ending more than 18 months of restrictions on international travel that separated families and cost the global travel industry hundreds of billions of dollars in tourism revenue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman and Ashley Wong
title: N.Y.C. public schools open vaccination sites for 5- to 11-year-olds.
description: The first day of vaccinations for younger kids at their schools went fairly smoothly, though some clinics ran out of supplies.
content: Paul LaCorte, the parent of a 5- and a 7-year-old at P.S. 40 in Manhattan, arrived early, hoping to get his children vaccinated against the coronavirus at a clinic the city was hosting there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Novak Djokovic Gets His Groove Back in Paris
description: He bolstered his claim to being the best men’s player of this era by securing the year-end No. 1 ranking for a record seventh year.
content: PARIS — When Novak Djokovic was 7, the world of elite tennis was a distant place, visible only on the television screen of his parents’ pizzeria in the Serbian mountains or the modest family apartment in Belgrade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: As Deaths Rise in N.Y.C. Jails, Oversight Board Fails to Raise Alarm
description: Do your job “before someone dies,” an advocate pleaded at a meeting of the city Board of Correction, which has the power to monitor Rikers Island.
content: Of all the agencies that share responsibility for New York City’s troubled jail system, only one was established by the city solely to monitor conditions behind bars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: French Catholic Church Will Sell Assets to Compensate Abuse Victims
description: The measure was one of several measures announced by French bishops, one month after a landmark report on sexual abuse by clergy members in France.
content: PARIS — The Roman Catholic Church in France will sell some of its assets to compensate victims of sexual abuse, French bishops announced on Monday, one month after the release of a sweeping report on sexual abuse by the clergy that has fueled growing calls for reform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Oscar Pistorius, Olympic Runner Convicted of Murder, Is Up for Parole
description: The double-amputee sprinter has served half his sentence for killing his girlfriend. His victim’s parents were said to be “shocked” at the prospect of his release.
content: JOHANNESBURG — Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee Olympic sprinter who garnered global headlines after killing his girlfriend in 2013, may soon be paroled from prison, South African corrections officials said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: A Chip Shop That’s Not a Chip Shop: Dame, in the Village
description: With exceptional fish and chips, the chef Ed Szymanski turned a pandemic pop-up into a postpandemic destination.
content: New York has so few great seafood restaurants you’d think we were the largest city in Nebraska. Outside of the most exclusive sushi bars, kitchens that are entirely devoted to handling fish with care and finesse are rare. When I told a friend I was reviewing a new seafood restaurant that was actually kind of nice, he said, “Nice? Like Le Bernardin?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: U.S. Covid Deaths Get Even Redder
description: The partisan gap in Covid’s death toll has grown faster over the past month than at any previous point.
content: As 2020 wound down, there were good reasons to believe that the death toll during the pandemic’s first year might have been worse in red America. There were also good reasons to think it might have been worse in blue America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Why the Republican Candidate for New Jersey Governor Hasn’t Conceded
description: Gov. Phil Murphy’s Republican opponent, Jack Ciattarelli, was trailing by about 65,500 votes. He is waiting for 70,000 provisional ballots to be counted.
content: Hours after polls closed in the unexpectedly tight race for New Jersey governor, the Democratic incumbent, Philip D. Murphy, and his Republican challenger, Jack Ciattarelli, took the stages at their campaign parties and said it would take more time for the results to be finalized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Excited passengers board flights from London to the U.S.
description: Long lines formed at Heathrow Airport for the first scheduled trips to the United States since the Biden administration lifted a travel ban.
content: Thousands of excited passengers flocked to Heathrow Airport on Monday for the first flights to the United States out of London since the Biden administration lifted a travel ban on many international visitors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: The Democrats’ No Good, Very Bad Day Changes the Landscape
description: Bridges of America, rejoice!
content: Gail Collins: Gee, Bret, the Democrats lose a gubernatorial election in Virginia and the next thing you know, the nation has a brand-new $1 trillion public works program. Who says democracy isn’t efficient?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Randal Quarles, formerly the Fed’s vice chair for supervision, will leave the central bank at the end of December.
description: Mr. Quarles’s term as a governor could have stretched until 2032. His departure will give the Biden administration more room to remake the Fed.
content: Randal K. Quarles, a Federal Reserve governor who spent four years overseeing bank supervision, will step down from the Fed in December — opening an additional seat that will allow the Biden administration to reshape the central bank’s leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Edgar Sandoval
title: Houston Officials Worried About Crowd Control Before Travis Scott Took the Stage
description: On the day of the show, the Houston police chief said that he visited Mr. Scott in his trailer and shared his concerns about the crowd.
content: HOUSTON — Concert organizers and Houston city officials knew that the crowd at a music festival planned by Travis Scott, a favorite local rapper turned megastar, could be difficult to control. That’s what happened two years earlier, the last time Mr. Scott held his Astroworld Festival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Jill Biden Kicks Off Covid Vaccine Campaign for Young Children
description: The first lady and the surgeon general visited an elementary school in Virginia as part of a strategy to enlist schools in promoting the vaccine.
content: McLEAN, Va. — Franklin Sherman Elementary School made medical history in 1954, when 114 of its students became the first healthy American children to be vaccinated against polio as part of a nationwide clinical trial. They called themselves “polio pioneers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yewande Komolafe
title: These Thanksgiving Recipes Aren’t Just Side Dishes. They’re My Memories.
description: For Yewande Komolafe, the holiday is as much about learning her loved ones’ traditions as it is about the meal. She shares the recipes she’s collected.
content: Roast turkey is not and has never been my passion, but I have come to love Thanksgiving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darby Saxbe and Sofia Cardenas
title: What Paternity Leave Does for a Father’s Brain
description: Taking time off from work when a baby is born is essential for mothers and fathers.
content: After President Biden left paid family leave out of his Build Back Better Act last month, a familiar marshaling of forces took place. Women’s groups and female leaders protested. Senator Patty Murray of Washington said Democrats should not “tell all the women in this country that they can’t have paid leave.” Democratic leaders, well aware that women are the base of the party, have restored four weeks of family leave, at least for now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery
title: Retailers Scramble to Attract Workers Ahead of the Holidays
description: Signing bonuses, higher wages, even college tuition. Companies are using perks to entice new employees in an industry that has been battered by the pandemic.
content: Macy’s is offering referral bonuses of up to $500 for each friend or family member that employees recruit to join the company. Walmart is paying as much as $17 an hour to start and has begun offering free college tuition to its workers. And some Amazon warehouse jobs now command signing bonuses of up to $3,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño, Flávia Milhorance and Jack Nicas
title: Brazil’s Far-Right Disinformation Pushers Find a Safe Space on Telegram
description: In a social media ecosystem facing mounting pressure to combat fake news and polarization, Telegram is the most permissive disseminator of content — and disinformation.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — Shortly after President Donald J. Trump was banned from Twitter early this year, Brazil’s like-minded leader made a plea to his millions of followers on the site.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘Sooryavanshi’ Review: Cops on a Crusade
description: The latest in Rohit Shetty’s Bollywood cop franchise is both overstuffed and paper-thin.
content: Over the last decade, the Bollywood director Rohit Shetty has built a flamboyant Cop Cinematic Universe with crowd pleasers — “Singham,” “Singham Returns,” and “Simmba” — about righteous policemen with anger issues and physics-defying stunt capabilities. Shetty’s latest installment tries to up the ante (a fool’s errand, given how over-the-top each of the prior movies already is) by smushing them all together: The movie’s titular Anti-Terrorism Squad officer, played by the action veteran Akshay Kumar, is joined by the supercops of the previous films (Ajay Devgn and Ranveer Singh) for a bullets-and-brawn extravaganza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Lynsea Garrison, Robert Jimison, Clare Toeniskoetter, Daniel Guillemette, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: A Case That Could Transform America’s Relationship With Guns
description: In a potentially landmark Supreme Court decision about the Second Amendment, how will the justices rule?
content: The U.S. Supreme Court is gearing up to rule on an area of the law that it has been silent on for over a decade: the Second Amendment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Travel, Astroworld, Elon Musk: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Alsatian Delights From Gabriel Kreuther
description: The chef offers the recipes of his youth along with the finesse of his work in a lavish new cookbook.
content: There are two Gabriel Kreuthers on display in his lavish new gift-worthy book, “Gabriel Kreuther, The Spirit of Alsace: A Cookbook,” written with Michael Ruhlman. First up is the son of the province in eastern France: His love letter to his region covers the traditions of farm and table, with the expected tarte flambée, choucroute garnie, baeckeoffe, kougelhopf and a raft of Christmas cookies. Then you have the accomplished chef’s restaurant recipes, often inspired by Alsace, like foie gras terrine with separate steps for sauce, crust and finishing; lamb cooked in hay, requiring six recipes; cabbage stuffed with langoustines and scallops; and the marathon of Black Forest Craquelin that calls for nine preparations. But even at their most complex, the recipes hold promise for the home cook. A button mushroom soup stands deliciously on its own without the chorizo-potato raviolis alongside, and can easily be made to serve four or six instead of 12. And no matter the recipe, Mr. Kreuther fine-tunes the necessary details, even down to explaining the best way to line a terrine with plastic wrap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: How to Nurture Kindness in a New Generation
description: In “Social Justice Parenting,” Traci Baxley emphasizes the rewards of teaching our children to empathize with and care for others.
content: The holidays will soon be upon us. What is likely to make you feel better — receiving a gift, or giving one to someone in need? Research is clear that, as the proverb goes, it’s better to give than to receive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Cancer Nearly Took His Life. But the New York Marathon Awaited.
description: Almost a year ago to the day, the elite runner Tommy Rivers Puzey learned to sit up in a bed again. On Sunday, he attempted the New York City Marathon.
content: Almost a year ago to the day, Tommy Rivers Puzey, a professional runner who has won or placed in big city marathons and other endurance events, learned to sit up in bed again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Gandel
title: Behind Elon Musk’s Twitter Poll Is a Tax Bill Coming Due
description: He asked whether he should sell 10 percent of his stock, and Twitter voters said yes. Stock options he was granted in 2012 are “a ticking tax time bomb,” one expert said.
content: Elon Musk may have already been compelled to sell a sizable portion of his Tesla shares even if he hadn’t issued an unusual Twitter pledge over the weekend. Mr. Musk on Saturday polled Twitter users on whether he should sell 10 percent of his stake in his company. The poll appeared to be a response to a Democratic proposal to tax the unrealized gains of billionaires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Why Republicans Won in a New York County Where Democrats Outnumber Them
description: Voters readily ousted Democrats in Nassau County on Long Island, electing Republicans down the ballot.
content: It wasn’t the high taxes in Nassau County, or the recent changes to New York’s bail laws that drove Lizette Sonsini, a former Democrat, to vote Republican this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Elon Musk’s ‘Ticking Tax Time Bomb’
description: Is the Tesla chief about to sell a big chunk of his shares?
content: Elon Musk appears to have used an impending stock option deadline to make a political point. Over the weekend, the Tesla C.E.O. surveyed his millions of Twitter followers about whether he should sell a chunk of his shares in the electric car company. “Much is made lately of unrealized gains being a means of tax avoidance, so I propose selling 10% of my Tesla stock,” he tweeted, committing to abide by the results of the poll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: How Public Preschool Can Help, and How to Make Sure It Doesn’t Hurt
description: Congress is considering universal pre-K and subsidies for child care. Research shows how these policies can benefit children, and when they can backfire.
content: Congress is nearing a vote on a plan to spend around $390 billion over six years on early childhood care and education in the United States. Government-supported child care can have lifelong benefits for young children and their families, but it depends how the policies are designed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: Over 100,000 New York City public school students were homeless last year, data show.
description: An urgent crisis awaits the incoming mayor, Eric Adams, in January.
content: More than 101,000 public school students in New York City lacked permanent housing during the last school year, according to new city data released Monday, a staggering figure that demonstrates the profound stakes of school closures and educational disruptions during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Felsenthal
title: Jacqueline de Jong Paints It All
description: At 82, the artist continues to make works that respond to the world around her, whether they comment on the migrant crisis or transform the potatoes she grows in her garden.
content: The Dutch artist Jacqueline de Jong, 82, lives alone with her cat, Shosha, in a vertiginous central Amsterdam townhouse that she bought with her late husband, Tom Weyland, in 1992. Just before the pandemic, de Jong installed an elevator to ease her climb to the attic, where she keeps a painting studio tucked under the eaves. Going up and down in that lift — a “little prison,” she says — got her thinking about the tension between movement and confinement, a theme already on her mind as she watched the news, horrified by the unfolding refugee crises in Idlib, Syria, and the Mediterranean. It’s a testament to de Jong’s eclectic sensibility that she braided those thoughts together in a new body of work: “Border-Line,” a series of oil-stick paintings that mash up news imagery of the global migrant crisis — the rescue boat Sea Watch 4, huddled masses on rafts, fire at the Mória refugee camp on the island of Lesbos — with the kind of monstrous, cartoonish figures that frequently appear on her canvases. Here, they are ghostly lugs, hovering at the edge of the action, sometimes encased in little elevatorlike boxes (that de Jong made these paintings during Covid lockdown — “very much in confinement” — adds another layer). The series reflects her “personal desire to do something” about the migrant situation, but these ungainly interlopers seem to sound a note of self-critique: Like the artist and her presumed viewer, they empathize and gawk in equal measure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: U.S. Travel Ban Ends, Easing Personal Frustrations and Diplomatic Tension
description: Europeans were kept apart from family and friends as the ban dragged on long after E.U. leaders had opened their borders.
content: BRUSSELS — Laurence Tesson, from Douai in northern France, has been aching for three years to see her 34-year-old son who lives in California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
title: Despite Abuses of NSO Spyware, Israel Will Lobby U.S. to Defend It
description: As a new accusation surfaces that NSO’s software may have been used to spy on Palestinians, Israeli officials say it is crucial to national security.
content: JERUSALEM — Hacking software sold by the NSO Group, an Israeli surveillance firm, has been used to spy on journalists, opposition groups and rights activists. There have been so many accusations of abuse that the Biden administration slapped sanctions on the company last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Fed warns of social media ‘echo chambers’ that pump up meme stocks.
description: A Federal Reserve report found the financial system showed broad signs of resilience, but it suggested so-called meme stocks could pose some risks.
content: Stocks that experience major volatility as a result of social media attention — often called meme stocks — have not threatened broader financial stability so far but could open the door to vulnerabilities, the Federal Reserve said in a report on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu and Sabrina Imbler
title: Fully vaccinated and want to visit the U.S.? Here are some of the basics.
description: Here is what we know right now about the long-awaited reopening.
content: On Monday, the United States lifted travel restrictions for international visitors from 33 countries who are fully vaccinated against the coronavirus, ending an 18-month ban that has separated families and loved ones worldwide and taken a toll on the tourism industry. The reopening comes just ahead of the holiday season, and airlines are anticipating some chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: New Yorkers’ Long Wait for Sports Betting by Phone Is Nearly Over
description: The Gaming Commission, playing catch-up with New Jersey, bypassed Jay-Z and granted licenses to two coalitions that include big names in betting.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — After years of delays as a booming market emerged in neighboring states, New York formally announced the winners of two licenses for mobile sports betting on Monday, though residents may still have to wait months to gamble from their cellphones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winston Choi-Schagrin
title: More Than 40 Nations Pledge to Cut Emissions From Their Health Industries
description: The plans, while short on specifics, represent a notable step toward cutting greenhouse gas emissions from hospitals and the health care industry, a sizable emitter globally.
content: More than 40 countries have pledged to cut greenhouse-gas emissions across their health systems, World Health Organization officials said late Monday, representing the largest global effort to date to try to reduce contributions by the world’s hospitals and health care industry to global warming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Bledsoe, Durwood Zaelke and Gabrielle Dreyfus
title: How to Limit Temperature Increases in the Very Near Term
description: Without more action, we risk runaway warming.
content: If the years of devastating droughts, floods, heat waves and wildfires since the Paris climate agreement was adopted have taught us anything, it’s that we have underestimated the pace of extreme, destabilizing climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annabelle Williams
title: Rabbi Earl A. Grollman, 96, Dies; Sought to Demystify Death and Grief
description: He wrote prolifically about grief, counseled the bereaved after 9/11 and the Oklahoma City bombing and paid particular attention to children. “Grief is the price we pay for love,” he’d say.
content: Rabbi Earl A. Grollman, a prolific writer on grief who became widely known for ministering to those mourning the death of loved ones in the 9/11 attacks, the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing and other times of loss, died on Oct. 15 at his home in Belmont, Mass. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: In Romania, Hard-Hit by Covid, Doctors Fight Vaccine Refusal
description: An anti-vaccine clarion call by leading religious figures, echoed by prominent politicians and social media, helps explain why Romania now has the world’s highest Covid death rate.
content: COPACENI, Romania — As a new wave of the coronavirus pandemic crashed over Eastern Europe last month, devastating unvaccinated populations, an Orthodox Church bishop in southern Romania offered solace to his flock: “Don’t be fooled by what you see on TV — don’t be scared of Covid.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Brain Drain From Britain Delivers Financial Boon to Estonia
description: The former Soviet satellite state is welcoming British companies looking to escape the tangle of regulations and financial obstacles of doing business in Europe.
content: At first Vicky Brock struggled to place Estonia on the map. And when she flew to the Baltic nation last December, she took just hand luggage, assuming it would be a short trip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Weighs Case Against F.B.I. for Spying on Muslims
description: The justices considered whether the state secrets doctrine required dismissal on national security grounds of a case claiming religious discrimination.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday wrestled with the scope of the state secrets doctrine, debating whether it allows the government merely to withhold evidence that it says could harm national security or whether it entitles the government to insist that lawsuits against it based on government secrets be dismissed entirely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: New Zealand’s biggest city will ease lockdown restrictions.
description: The lifting of rules comes as the country records some of its highest daily case numbers since the pandemic began.
content: Auckland, New Zealand’s largest city, will relax many virus restrictions nearly 12 weeks into its lockdown, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced at a news conference on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: ornery
description: This word has appeared in 21 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: New York’s cultural institutions have a lot at stake as international visitors return.
description: The arts have suffered with a big source of ticket sales missing throughout the pandemic.
content: Few sectors of New York City’s economy lean more heavily on foreign tourists for revenue than the arts, and, as international travel to the United States restarts Monday, the city’s cultural institutions are more than eager for them to return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Feldman
title: Is the Supreme Court on Its Way to Becoming a Conservative Bastion?
description: Linda Greenhouse’s “Justice on the Brink” looks back at the Supreme Court’s last year, with intimations of what we can expect in the future.
content: JUSTICE ON THE BRINK
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: How an Artist Listens to the Voices in His Head
description: Josh Ritter talks about how his novel “The Great Glorious Goddamn of It All” changed as he wrote it and the importance of creative work that doesn’t eat up its creator.
content: The singer and songwriter Josh Ritter’s musical work is often praised for its imaginative and deeply considered lyrics. His first novel, “Bright’s Passage” (2011), started as a song before Ritter transformed it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Elaine Romagnoli, Longtime Fixture of Lesbian Nightlife, Dies at 79
description: The bustling downtown bars that Ms. Romagnoli created, beginning in 1972, became central to New York City’s gay community.
content: Elaine Romagnoli, the creator of the notable New York lesbian bars Bonnie & Clyde’s, the Cubby Hole and Crazy Nanny’s, died on Oct. 28 at her home in Manhattan. She was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Don Clark
title: Chip Shortage Creates New Power Players
description: Low-profile chip makers with aging factories have become surprisingly powerful, leading to industry changes that may outlive the pandemic-fueled supply crunch.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Since 1989, Microchip Technology has operated in an unglamorous backwater of the electronics industry, making chips called microcontrollers that add computing power to cars, industrial equipment and many other products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Zagoria
title: Coach K’s Farewell Tour Is Coming. His Replacement Is Reloading on Talent.
description: Jon Scheyer, the men’s basketball coach who will replace Mike Krzyzewski at Duke next season, has already taken over recruiting.
content: When the curtain lifts on a new college basketball season on Tuesday night, all eyes will be on Mike Krzyzewski, the legendary Duke men’s coach, as he leads the No. 9 Blue Devils against No. 10 Kentucky in the Champions Classic at Madison Square Garden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Thousands of Canadians head for the southern United States again.
description: With the border opening to tourists, thousands of Canadian “snowbirds” are on their way to Florida, Arizona and California with campers in tow.
content: It had been a decade since Judy and Wayne Peters had spent the winter in their home country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Bans on Critical Race Theory Threaten Free Speech, Advocacy Group Says
description: A report by PEN America, which surveys more than 50 bills proposed across the country, appeals to a principle that has lost its luster for many on the left and right.
content: Over the past year, critical race theory has gone from arcane legal concept to potent political rallying cry, as Republican legislatures have rushed to introduce bills banning it and other “divisive concepts” in public schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘Succession’ Recap, Season 3, Episode 4: Meep-Meep
description: After last week’s punishingly bleak episode, this week “Succession” brought some much-needed comic relief alongside the ongoing melodrama.
content: Last week’s punishingly bleak “Succession” episode was maybe the roughest since Season 2’s “Hunting” (a.k.a.“Boar on the Floor”). But as often happens in this series, this week’s episode pulls back a bit, bringing some much-needed comic relief alongside the ongoing melodrama. In “Lion in the Meadow,” the Roys take a break from scorching the Earth and get back to more subtle power plays, using schoolyard insults and small gestures of disrespect to needle each other. It’s all so oddly delightful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Emotional reunions at U.S. airports.
content: The U.S. reopened its borders for fully vaccinated travelers from dozens of countries on Monday, ending 18 months of restrictions on international travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Crossword Constructor Resource Guide
description: A collection of tools for people looking to make their own puzzles.
content: Some constructors still use graph paper and an expansive collection of dictionaries, but most use software. CrossFire is the most popular choice among professional constructors, but there are a number of excellent options.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $975,000 Homes in California
description: A geodesic dome house in South Lake Tahoe, a three-bedroom loft in Long Beach and a Victorian home in Alameda.
content: The Lake Tahoe area has long been a destination for second-home buyers from elsewhere in the state, a trend that has picked up considerably in recent years. This house is in Montgomery Estates, a neighborhood that is particularly appealing, thanks to its proximity to the Heavenly Mountain ski resort, about four miles away (or a 10-minute drive), and High Meadow Trailhead, popular with hikers and mountain bikers, about half a mile away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Many Variations of Mexican Chicken Soup
description: Pati Jinich will discuss the comforts of regional chicken soup at a virtual class at the 92nd Street Y.
content: For soup season, expanding the inventory of warm, steaming bowls of richness is ever so welcome. An hourlong virtual class that explores the regional variations for chicken soup in Mexico will be led later this month by the cookbook author and television chef Pati Jinich, who has written for The Times, for the 92nd Street Y’s program. Those that enroll can access the class later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austan Goolsbee
title: How to Think About the Covid Recession
description: When will the U.S. economy improve?
content: Americans everywhere remain concerned about getting past what feels like a never-ending litany of Covid-19-induced economic problems, from out-of-stock products to inflation and continued fears of exposure to illness when going out. When will it finally end?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: When the Taliban Are in Your Bedroom
description: As armed Taliban inspected the New York Times bureau in Kabul, they were escorted by a journalist who used to be a U.S. Marine. The photo of him in uniform was plain for all to see, and ponder.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — When the Taliban are in your bedroom and there’s a photograph of you on the wall holding an American flag, a rifle and dressed like a recruiting commercial for the Marines, you have to keep it together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Hallie Golden
title: Costly tests may deter Canadians from making quick trips to the U.S.
description: Canada requires travelers to present the results of an expensive coronavirus test to enter, deterring short hops across the border.
content: Throughout the pandemic, Canadians have been able to travel to the United States for nonessential reasons like visiting family and friends, but there was a catch: They had to fly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Winter Heating Bills Loom as the Next Inflation Threat
description: After plunging during the pandemic as the economy slowed, energy prices have roared upward. Washington is already moving to offer homeowners relief.
content: With consumers already dealing with the fastest price increases in decades, another unwelcome uptick is on the horizon: a widely expected increase in winter heating bills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Haramis
title: Goodbye to the Murse, and Hello to Handbags for All
description: As gender norms have relaxed over the past few decades, the men’s carryall has gone from sitcom punchline to quasi-ubiquitous accessory.
content: SLANG OF THE past few decades has been clunky on the subject of men who care about fashion or grooming. To go shopping was to be a metrosexual. To wear makeup was to apply guyliner. If we endeavored to explore our bodies with a trimmer, we were, ugh, manscaping. The goofiest of these portmanteaus, and one of the more enduring, involved the carryall. The murse, or the equally deplorable man bag, entered the pop-cultural conversation as a gender-normative joke: In 1998, Jerry Seinfeld’s TV alter ego, needing an alternative to his ballooning wallet, acquires a handbag (“It’s not a purse, it’s European!”); a year later, in a “Friends” episode titled “The One With Joey’s Bag,” the dopey soap opera actor struggles to give up his new accessory, even after it costs him an acting job. When he looks to his friend Rachel for advice, she stammers, “I’m not saying that you shouldn’t have a bag, I just … it’s just there are other bags, you know, that are maybe a little less, um ... controversial.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: 2 Ex-Officers Who Used Tasers on a Man Over 50 Times Are Convicted of Murder
description: Prosecutors called the actions of Joshua Taylor and Brandon Dingman, former officers in Wilson, Okla., a “substantial factor” in the 2019 death of Jared Lakey.
content: Two former Oklahoma police officers were convicted on Friday of second-degree murder for using their Tasers a total of more than 50 times on an unarmed man who later died in 2019, according to court records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: 60 Criminal Cases Are Thrown Out Because of 3 Detectives’ Misconduct
description: The testimony of three New York Police Department detectives in dozens of cases in Queens was called into question after they were convicted of crimes or misconduct.
content: The Queens district attorney’s office asked a judge Monday to toss out 60 criminal cases that relied on work by three former New York Police Department detectives who were later convicted of perjury, sexual assault or official misconduct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A peek inside China.
content: China is preparing for a long winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Jan. 6 Panel Subpoenas Flynn and Eastman, Scrutinizing Election Plot
description: The latest batch of subpoenas from the House select committee investigating the Capitol riot also includes officials from former President Donald J. Trump’s re-election campaign.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol issued new subpoenas on Monday for a half-dozen allies of former President Donald J. Trump, including his former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn, as it moved its focus to an orchestrated effort to overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: Evictions are mounting in the United States, but at a slower pace than many tenants and advocates feared.
description: In Indianapolis, eviction courts are packed as judges make their way through a monthslong backlog of cases. In Detroit, advocates are rushing to knock on the doors of tenants facing possible eviction. In Gainesville, Fla., landlords are filing evictions at a rapid pace as displaced tenants resort to relatives’ couches for places to sleep or seek cheaper rents outside the city.
content: In Indianapolis, eviction courts are packed as judges make their way through a monthslong backlog of cases. In Detroit, advocates are rushing to knock on the doors of tenants facing possible eviction. In Gainesville, Fla., landlords are filing evictions at a rapid pace as displaced tenants resort to relatives’ couches for places to sleep or seek cheaper rents outside the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: An Urban Problem: Rats on the Rise
description: The rodent population has surged in the pandemic.
content: It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at rats in New York, which have become a more serious problem than ever. And with the New York Comedy Festival beginning tonight, we will also look at humor at this moment in the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and Lisa Friedman
title: Can Glasgow Deliver on a Global Climate Deal?
description: Negotiators from about 200 countries are entering Week 2 of climate talks trying to resolve big issues around money, transparency and timelines.
content: GLASGOW — The international climate summit here has been billed by its chief organizer as the “last, best hope” to save the planet. But as the United Nations conference enters its second week and negotiators from 197 countries knuckle down to finalize a new agreement to tackle global warming, attendees were sharply divided over how much progress is being made.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: She Died With Long Covid. Should Her Organs Have Been Donated?
description: Heidi Ferrer’s family feared her organs were unsafe. The case points to gaps in protocols for organ donation amid the pandemic.
content: Covid-19 ravaged Heidi Ferrer’s body and soul for over a year, and in May the “Dawson’s Creek” screenwriter killed herself in Los Angeles. She had lost all hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Why Are Republicans Now Loving the Sweet Sound of Electric Vehicles?
description: Ford’s plans for multi-billion dollar manufacturing sites for electric vehicles has Tennessee and Kentucky singing a different tune on cleaner energy.
content: NASHVILLE — Marsha Blackburn, the Republican senior senator from Tennessee, is not about building a green future. In 2008, as a House member, she voted against tax incentives for renewable energy. During her 2018 Senate campaign and before, she expressed doubt about human responsibility for climate change. This year, when the United States rejoined the Paris agreement to cut greenhouse gas emissions, Ms. Blackburn complained that the move would “kill another 400,000 jobs and lead our country away from energy independence.” In August she voted against the Senate’s bipartisan infrastructure bill, calling it “the gateway to socialism” and “the down payment on the Green New Deal.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Why the ‘Scariest’ Night Didn’t Keep LaMarcus Aldridge Out of the N.B.A.
description: Aldridge, the veteran Nets center, briefly retired after 15 seasons because of a heart issue. He was depressed — then determined to return.
content: In April, Nets center LaMarcus Aldridge was staring into the abyss. He stunned the basketball world by announcing his retirement from the N.B.A. after experiencing an irregular heartbeat during a game. Aldridge had learned during his rookie season in 2006-7 that he had Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, which causes a rapid heartbeat, but that night in April, he said, was “one of the scariest” in his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: On Chicago’s West Side, Urgent Needs Collide With Washington Compromises
description: Activists say the needs of struggling communities in Chicago and elsewhere vastly exceed the billions Congress is spending.
content: CHICAGO — Democrats in Washington want to talk about what has made it into President Biden’s domestic legislation. Chris Brown on Chicago’s West Side wants to talk about what has been cut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Military Can’t Find ISIS Safe House That Prompted Kabul Drone Strike
description: The Pentagon’s latest admission illustrates the botched intelligence behind the strike that mistakenly killed 10 civilians in August.
content: WASHINGTON — The U.S. military has not located a suspected Islamic State safe house in Kabul, Afghanistan, that officials initially said led to an American drone strike on Aug. 29 that mistakenly killed 10 civilians, including seven children, according to two senior military officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan
title: ‘Re-Fund the Police’? Why It Might Not Reduce Crime.
description: Other anti-crime measures might be more effective, experts say, and avoid the downsides of policing.
content: In liberal Portland, Ore., which is facing its most violent year on record, the mayor announced a plan on Wednesday to put 200 more police officers on the streets. His announcement came a day after voters in Atlanta and in Seattle signaled their support for mayoral candidates who promised not to roll back the police force, but to expand it. In Maryland last month, Gov. Larry Hogan announced $150 million to “Re-fund the police.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Paytm, a payments company, is aiming to raise $2.5 billion amid India’s stock boom.
description: One97 Communications, the app’s parent company, has drawn interest from institutional investors as online shopping in India expands.
content: With stocks on a tear in India, the parent company of Paytm, a leading digital payments app, went public on Monday with hopes of becoming the country’s largest initial public offering.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Inspired to run a marathon? Here’s how to start training for it.
description: Whether you’re looking to start running for the first time, or to improve your marathon time, try our New York Times guides to running.
content: If the New York City Marathon inspired you to start running, to train for a marathon or to run your next race even faster, we can help you get started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: N.Y.’s governor promises grants for employers and laid-off workers in the ailing tourism industry.
description: Ms. Hochul said the state would make payments of $2,750 to as many as 36,000 workers who lost jobs during the pandemic as part of a $450 million package to help the tourism industry.
content: New York’s governor, Kathy Hochul, proposed a $450 million package of state spending on Monday to help the state’s struggling tourism industry, including one-time grants to laid-off workers and their employers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Nicole Perlroth
title: Justice Dept. Brings New Charges in Ransomware Attacks
description: The department said it had charged a Russian national in one attack and recovered $6.1 million in ransom. It also arrested a Ukrainian man for another attack.
content: The Justice Department said on Monday that it had brought charges against a Russian national whom it accused of conducting ransomware attacks against American government entities and businesses, including one that temporarily shut down the meat supply giant JBS.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alicia Kennedy, Jennifer Livingston and Haidee Findlay-Levin
title: The Latest Trend in Baking? Making a Mess
description: A new generation of confectioners is eschewing the primness and precision of traditional cakes and creating confections as delightful as they are subversive.
content: Billie Belo will never write “Happy Birthday” on her cakes. As the baker behind Cakes for No Occasion, she sees her offerings more as sculptures than comestible commodities: The tiered monstrosities ooze and drip. Her neon or pastel buttercream is often pocked with bulbous orbs that Belo, 38, doesn’t define as, say, truffles or cream puffs; in her decorating language, they’re simply balls, in flavors like lychee or raspberry, and they make her desserts seem not just alive but unwell. After studying painting at New York’s Grand Central Atelier, she began baking for her friends’ restaurant, Lil’ Deb’s Oasis, in Hudson, N.Y., a few years ago, then started her online business — each one-of-a-kind cake is sold by email from her Manhattan apartment — in 2018 after refining an impasto style that betrays what she calls the “tight” Victorian look of traditional cakes, where lines are clean and excess frosting is swept away. “There’s just so much caution in [that] realist style, and I felt imprisoned by it,” she says. “With cake, I want it to explode.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Dunne
title: What We Learned From Week 9 in the N.F.L.
description: Baker Mayfield took control of a Browns team that looked ready to collapse. The Packers got their first long look at Jordan Love, and Dak Prescott and Josh Allen struggled in shocking upsets.
content: It has been the running joke throughout Baker Mayfield’s four-year career: The hip-thrusting franchise player with an Everyman’s comedic timing performs consistently better in TV commercials than on a football field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Putu Sayoga
title: Inside a Volcanic Ritual on the Indonesian Island of Java
description: During the Hindu ceremony of Yadnya Kasada, the Tenggerese people toss offerings — food, money, flowers, livestock — into the hazy crater of Mount Bromo.
content: When I reached the top of the volcano and glanced back down, I could see the fog hovering over the thick carpet of ash that surrounds its base. A few golden rays of sunlight were beginning to streak across the eastern horizon, illuminating the temple, Pura Luhur Poten, that I had visited earlier in the morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Elbein
title: These Oddly Named Worms May Have Been the First Hermits
description: So-called “penis worms” get attention for all the wrong reasons. But new research finds they may have been early pioneers in a creative survival technique.
content: Consider this evolutionary dilemma, faced by the aquatic and squishy: How do you survive in hostile, predator-filled oceans?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Before the Astroworld Tragedy, Travis Scott’s ‘Raging’ Made Him a Star
description: The multiplatinum rapper earned a reputation for concerts that teetered on the edge of mayhem. Then eight people died during his performance in Houston on Friday.
content: Travis Scott has always been a showman first and foremost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Wirecutter workers threaten a walkout during a peak shopping week over contract delays.
description: Their union, which is seeking higher salary minimums and guaranteed raises, has been negotiating with The New York Times Company for two years.
content: Union members at Wirecutter, a product review website owned by The New York Times Company, said on Monday that they were prepared to stop work during the busy shopping period around Black Friday if a deal for a contract was not reached.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Rats Amok in the Park, on the Block and Even at Your Table
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 8, 2021.
content: “It’s gross and it’s kind of unnerving.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: ‘Insecure’ Recap, Season 5, Episode 3: Slow Start to Fatherhood
description: This week, Lawrence learns that fatherhood may not look like what he imagined.
content: At the end of the season premiere of “Insecure,” Issa broke up with Lawrence. This week, we take a peek at what his life has been like since then.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Ed Sheeran, Streaming Star, Is No. 1 With Help From Album Sales
description: Sheeran’s “=” (pronounced “equals”) opens at the top of the Billboard 200 with modest streaming numbers for a star of his magnitude.
content: Ed Sheeran may be one of the world’s most popular artists on music streaming services, but his latest turn at No. 1 owes a lot to old-fashioned album sales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: 18 Warm-Up Activities to Engage Students Before They Read Nonfiction Texts
description: Here is a collection of our favorite “bell ringers,” “do nows” and “hooks” to grab students’ attention, along with examples from dozens of our daily lessons.
content: How can you make your students interested in reading informational texts, whether the topic is Syria or sneakers, space exploration, statistics, surfing, superheroes or “the souls of Black girls”? How can you help them make connections between unfamiliar topics and their own lives? How can you scaffold complex ideas to make them accessible for a wide variety of learners?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Rewriting China’s past.
content: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, will most likely take center stage in a new official summation of Communist Party history. The document is likely to exalt the leader as a peer of Mao Zedong and Deng Xiaoping before his expected re-election at a party congress late next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Krysten Chambrot
title: These Thanksgiving Recipes From the Archives Feel Timeless
description: Here are five dishes, all featured in the new edition of “The Essential New York Times Cookbook,” that will shine on your table.
content: What does it mean to explore a century and a half of New York Times recipes? For Amanda Hesser, the co-founder and chief executive of the cooking and home company Food52, and a former Times food writer and editor, it meant testing more than 1,400 dishes over six years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Iraq?
description: Can you find Iraq on a map? What else do you know about this Middle Eastern nation with about 41 million people?
content: Can you find Iraq on a map? What else do you know about this Middle Eastern nation with about 41 million people?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: What It Was Like to Run the Marathon
description: You could sense the smaller field of runners, but there’s nothing like having thousands of strangers cheer for you.
content: You could sense the smaller field of runners, but there’s nothing like having thousands of strangers cheer for you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Yuval Noah Harari Believes This Simple Story Can Save the Planet
description: “We need to stay away from the apocalyptic thinking that it’s too late and the world is ending and move toward a more practical thing: 2 percent of the budget.”
content: “We need to stay away from the apocalyptic thinking that it’s too late and the world is ending and move toward a more practical thing: 2 percent of the budget.”

author: By Nick Corasaniti, Reid J. Epstein, Taylor Johnston, Rebecca Lieberman and Eden Weingart
title: How Maps Reshape American Politics
description: We answer your most pressing questions about redistricting and gerrymandering.
content: We answer your most pressing questions about redistricting and gerrymandering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: 20 Vegetarian Recipes for the Perfect Sidesgiving
description: Vegetarians have always known the truth: It’s the sides that make the meal.
content: Vegetarians have always known the truth: It’s the sides that make the meal.
source.name: The New York Times

title: High Tide on Macdougal Street
description: The new Greenwich Village restaurant Dame is completely devoted to seafood. There’s not even a burger for the fish-phobic.
content: The new Greenwich Village restaurant Dame is completely devoted to seafood. There’s not even a burger for the fish-phobic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $975,000 in California
description: A geodesic dome house in South Lake Tahoe, a three-bedroom loft in Long Beach and a Victorian home in Alameda.
content: A geodesic dome house in South Lake Tahoe, a three-bedroom loft in Long Beach and a Victorian home in Alameda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Boyer
title: Reaching the Finish Line. Finally.
description: Runners and volunteers waited two years for the return of the New York City Marathon, after it was canceled in 2020 because of the coronavirus pandemic. This is what it was like to finally reach their goal.
content: Runners and volunteers waited two years for the return of the New York City Marathon, after it was canceled in 2020 because of the coronavirus pandemic. This is what it was like to finally reach their goal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Families Reunite as the U.S. Reopens to Vaccinated Travelers
description: Families who had been separated from loved ones for more than 18 months were finally able to see them again, after the U.S. lifted its travel ban for vaccinated foreigners.
content: Families who had been separated from loved ones for more than 18 months were finally able to see them again, after the U.S. lifted its travel ban for vaccinated foreigners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: White House to Defend Vaccination Rules for Large Companies
description: Karine Jean-Pierre, the White House’s principal deputy press secretary, recommended businesses move forward with plans to implement the administration’s Covid-19 vaccination or weekly testing requirements after a federal appeals court put a temporary block on them.
content: Karine Jean-Pierre, the White House’s principal deputy press secretary, recommended businesses move forward with plans to implement the administration’s Covid-19 vaccination or weekly testing requirements after a federal appeals court put a temporary block on them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Justice Dept. Announces Charges and Arrest in Ransomware Attacks
description: The Justice Department announced charges against a Russian national accused of conducting ransomware attacks against American government entities and businesses, as well as the arrest of a Ukrainian national in a separate attack.
content: The Justice Department announced charges against a Russian national accused of conducting ransomware attacks against American government entities and businesses, as well as the arrest of a Ukrainian national in a separate attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spacex
title: NASA’s SpaceX Crew-2 Departs International Space Station
description: Four astronauts from the mission undocked from the International Space Station in the Crew Dragon capsule and headed back to Earth after spending about half a year in space.
content: Four astronauts from the mission undocked from the International Space Station in the Crew Dragon capsule and headed back to Earth after spending about half a year in space.
source.name: The New York Times

title: For All Your Big Questions (and Small Ones, Too)
description: Must-hear episodes that cover everything from climate change to kindness.
content: A major United Nations scientific report concluded earlier this summer that the climate crisis is already here — and it’s going to get worse before it can get better.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Rough Road to the $1 Trillion Bill
description: Readers discuss the battles and compromises that led to the infrastructure bill’s approval. Also: The "Havana syndrome."
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Vegetarian Thanksgiving
description: Kay Chun’s new recipe for stuffed mushrooms with an escargot-flavored filling evokes the French classic.
content: Good morning. I once worked a kitchen station next to a wry Boston teenager who couldn’t believe his good fortune, to work where we did and not where he used to. “Beats stuffing mushroom caps at a sports bar in Allston,” he’d say about three times a day. It put me off mushroom caps for years.
source.name: The New York Times
